prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 6 Nitriles
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Due to Titan's time-variable atmosphere, this Science Goal should preferrably be observed close in time to Science Goal 2 (Band 7 Nitriles), ideally less than a week apart.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: A channel spacing of 244 kHz (resolution element ~0.54 km/s) will permit the narrow (~0.7-2.0 km/s) cores of Titan's high-altitude molecular emission lines to be adequately resolved. We have tried to reduce window fractional widths where possible, although C2H5CN, C2H3CN and CH3CN have multiple lines across their respective basebands, requiring the widest bandwidth to cover at least six lines of each to reach our target S/N and temperature sensitivity. HNC likely has broad wings (covering 10's of MHz), and the HC3N wings cover 100-200 MHz, while still having a narrow (~1 MHz wide) line core. The full 976 MHz bandwidth is required for CH3CN in baseband 3 in order to cover seven lines of the J=14-13 band at high enough resolution to resolve the line cores and allow accurate high altitude temperatures to be obtained. We opt not to use spectral averaging so as to preserve the Hanning line profiles that are more easily modeled by our radiative transfer package.

A beam size of 0.114'' is required to resolve the abundance gradients across Titan's ~0.8'' disk (with approx. 7 resolution elements), while still keeping integration times reasonable. This resolution will also allow us to resolve the ~0.1'' regions of high molecular abundance concentrated around Titan's poles (at latitudes > 75 deg). Titan's atmosphere is detectable out to a maximum of 1000 km from its surface. At 10 AU distance, this corresponds to an angular diameter of 0.98''.
Due to the brightness of Titan's continuum, the maps for HNC and C2H5CN might be adverseley affected by imaging dynamic range. An estimated imaging dynamic range of 117 and 288 will be required in order to reach the thermal noise limit for our HNC and C2H5CN maps. Although good image signal to noise ratios of 35 and 10, respectively will still be attainable if the maximum dynamic range limited is 100 (sufficient to adequately reach our science goals for mapping these species), we have found that a dynamic range of 200 was easily achieved for C2H5CN in Band 6 in Cycle 1 using standard calibration and imaging techniques. However, given that Titan is a bright and compact continuum source, with a very well known flux model, self-calibration of phases should enable a dynamic range of several hundred to be reached without difficulty.

RMS of 1.2 mJy over 488 kHz bandwidth is required for a 20-sigma measurement of the HNC 3-2 line profile (which has a predicted peak flux of 26 mJy/beam) and ~10 sigma detection of the C2H5CN lines. This high S/N is required in order to measure the detailed line profiles and detect the weak line wings, to enable the derivation of accurate vertical abundance profiles. 2D maps will be obtained by integrating over multiple spectral channels / multiple lines to obtain higher S/N images for each species. The sensitivity bandwidth of 488 kHz (0.54 km/s) is a close approximation to the estiamted spectral width of the narrowest part of the HNC line (which has FWHM ~0.7 km/s).

High data rates in this SB are a consequence of the multi-line CH3CN and C2H5CN observations necessary to measure accurate temperatures and abundances for these species. The lines are spread over ~500-1000 MHz. In addition, Titan's combination of narrow line cores (~1 km/s) and very broad wings (up to several hundred km/s) necessitate broad bandwidth at high spectral resolution. The scientific justification for observing these line profiles at high resolution is due to the high information content - the broad wings probe gases at low atmospheric altitude whereas the narrow cores probe high altitudes. Further, multiple lines of CH3CN are needed in order to derive the atmospheric temperature, necessitating the broadest bandwidth. In addition, significant continuum is ideally needed either side of these broad lines in order to properly constrain the continuum level for accurate spectral line modeling.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 7 Nitriles
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Due to Titan's time-variable atmosphere, this Science Goal should preferrably be observed close in time to Science Goal 1 (Band 6 Nitriles), ideally less than a week apart.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: A channel spacing of 244 kHz (resolution element 0.4 km/s) is required in order to properly resolve Titan's narrow (~0.7-2.0 km/s) molecular line cores. C2H5CN and C2H3CN have multiple lines across their respective basebands, requiring the widest bandwidth to cover at least six lines to reach the target map S/N. HNC likely has broad wings (covering 10's of MHz). The full 976 MHz bandwidth is required for CH3CN in baseband 1 in order to cover seven lines of the J=19-18 band at high enough resolution to resolve the line cores and allow accurate high altitude temperatures to be obtained. Spectral averaging adversely impacts the shape of the spectral resolution element, making accurate line profile modeling more difficult, so is not used.

A beam size of about 0.1'' is required to resolve the abundance gradients across Titan's ~0.8'' disk in reasonable integration times. This will also allow us to resolve the ~0.1'' regions of very high molecular abundance concentrated around Titan's poles (at latitudes > 75 deg). Titan's atmosphere is detectable out to a maximum of 1000 km from its surface. At 10 AU distance, this corresponds to an angular diameter of 0.98''.
An imaging dynamic range of about 350 will be required in order to reach the thermal noise limit for our C2H5CN maps, although this map is less important than the higher S/N map to be obtained in Band 6, but may be used to provide extra information on the C2H5CN distribution. Given that Titan has a well known continuum flux model, self calibration should enable a dynamic range of several hundred to be reached without difficulty. Although our theoretical CH3CN map S/N is over 200, a dynamic-range-limited S/N of 100 will still be easily sufficient to fulfill our scientific objective of accurately mapping this speices.

RMS of 3.8 mJy over 488 kHz bandwidth is required for a 20-sigma measurement of the HNC 4-3 line profile (which has a predicted peak flux of 73 mJy/beam), and ~3 sigma detection of the weaker C2H5CN lines. This high S/N is required for HNC in order to measure the detailed line profile and detect the weak line wings, enabling accurate vertical abundance profiles. 2D maps will be obtained by integrating over multiple spectral channels to obtain higher S/N images for each species. The sensitivity bandwidth of 488 kHz (0.4 km/s) is a close approximation to the estiamted spectral width of the narrowest part of the HNC line (which has FWHM ~0.7 km/s).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 7 HCN CO
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Due to Titan's time-variable atmosphere, this Science Goal should preferrably be observed close in time to Science Goals 1 and 2 (Band 6 and 7 Nitriles), ideally less than a month apart.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: As shown by Gurwell (2004), the CO 3-2 line wings extend about 1 GHz either side of the line center. In order to benefit from the low-altitude information provided by these broad wings, the widest bandwidth possible is requested, while still preserving sufficient resolution to measure the narrow spectral line peak (which contains the high-altitude information). A channel spacing of 976 kHz (0.85 km/s) and bandwidth 1875 GHz provides a good compromise between measuring the broad wings and the narrow line cores in this band. In addition, the lower frequency HCN isotopologue baseband is set immediately adjacent to the CO window in order to fully capture where the CO line wing meets continuum on the low frequency side. The HCN isotopologues also have broad wings and narrow cores, again requiring use of this broad bandwidth setting. We choose not to apply spectral averaging in order to preserve the instrumental line shape and facilitate the most accurate radiative transfer modeling.

A beam size of ~0.1'' is required to resolve the abundance gradients across Titan's ~0.8'' disk in reasonable integration times. This will also allow us to resolve the ~0.1'' regions of very high molecular abundance concentrated around Titan's poles (at latitudes > 75 deg). Titan's atmosphere is detectable out to a maximum of 1000 km from its surface. At 10 AU distance, this corresponds to an angular diameter of 0.98''.
ALMA's imaging dynamic range will limit the S/N of our HCN and CO maps to around 100, which is still sufficient to reach our science goals of accurately mapping these species. We will attempt to obtain higher dynamic range through self-calibration based on Titan's strong, accurately-known continuum flux model.

RMS of 3.5 mJy over 976 kHz bandwidth is required for a ~60-sigma measurement of the CO and HCN line profiles in this band. This high S/N is required in order to measure the detailed line profile and accurately measure the weak line wings so as to retrieve accurate vertical abundance and temperature profiles. The bandwidth of 976 kHz (0.85 km/s) corresponds to the somewhat broader width of the CO line peak compared with the species in the other SGs.

High data rates are a consequence of Titan's combination of very narrow line cores and very broad wings, necessitating broad bandwidth at high spectral resolution. The CO line wings span at least 2 GHz yet the line core is only a few km/s wide. H13CN and HC15N also exhibit broad wings. Significant continuum is also required near these lines in order to properly model the weak line wings. The scientific justification for observing the entire line profile at high resolution is due to the high information content - the broad wings probe gases at low atmospheric altitude whereas the narrow cores probe high altitudes.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Our pilot studies have hinted at a previously unidentified complexity in Titan's nitrile distributions - high-altitude asymmetries in the HNC and HC3N maps present a particular challenge to understanding. We propose to obtain high-sensitivity, high resolution followup observations of a selection of nitriles (including HCN, HNC, HC3N, C2H5CN and CH3CN) to help elucidate the processes involved in Titan's nitrogen chemistry and high-altitude atmospheric transport. Combined with contemporaneous CIRS spectroscopy, vertical abundance profiles will be derived for each species (with up to 50 independent resolution elements across Titan's disk), providing unprecedented, instantaneous 3-D spatial coverage. These data will be used to test and refine models for the production, destruction and transport of complex organic molecules in primitive, carbon and nitrogen-rich planetary atmospheres. Multi-line HNC observations will be used to constrain the HNC excitation temperature and ascertain whether non-thermal processes may be responsible for the anomalous longitudinal asymmetry observed by Cordiner et al. (2014).
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
